resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Library. Southern Folklife Collection.</corpname>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>Broadside.</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Broadside Collection, <unitdate>1962-1991</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <unitid>20289</unitid>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>280 items</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <abstract>Agnes (Sis) Cunningham, musician and magazine
    publisher of New York, N.Y., founded <title>Broadside</title>, a magazine
    devoted to topical songs, with her husband, Gordon Friesen, in the early 1960s. They recorded
    and published many of the leading folksingers of the folk revival. The collection contains
    materials from the <title>Broadside</title> offices. Sound recordings include
    open reel tapes and audio cassettes, many of which were used to transcribe topical folk songs
    for publication in <title>Broadside</title>. Additional recordings include demo
    tapes, live concert performances, and interviews, which were sent to the <title>Broadside</title> offices by friends, folk singers, and subscribers. The work of numerous
    performers is included (many of the most significant are listed in the online catalog terms
    below). Documentation materials include a log of the <title>Broadside</title>
    tapes, correspondence, and tape notes. The <title>Broadside</title> tape log is
    a list of the tapes in their original order. Correspondence and tape notes consist of materials
    included in the original tape boxes. Correspondence includes personal letters to Cunningham and
    Friesen from friends and contributors. Tape notes contain track listings of songs, dates of
    performances, and names of performers.</abstract>
                  <langmaterial>
                     <language>English.</language>
                  </langmaterial>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Broadside Collection, 1962-1991
resource.abstract: Agnes (Sis) Cunningham, musician and magazine    publisher of New York, N.Y., founded , a magazine    devoted to topical songs, with her husband, Gordon Friesen, in the early 1960s. They recorded    and published many of the leading folksingers of the folk revival. The collection contains    materials from the offices. Sound recordings include    open reel tapes and audio cassettes, many of which were used to transcribe topical folk songs    for publication in . Additional recordings include demo    tapes, live concert performances, and interviews, which were sent to the offices by friends, folk singers, and subscribers. The work of numerous    performers is included (many of the most significant are listed in the online catalog terms    below). Documentation materials include a log of the tapes, correspondence, and tape notes. The tape log is    a list of the tapes in their original order. Correspondence and tape notes consist of materials    included in the original tape boxes. Correspondence includes personal letters to Cunningham and    Friesen from friends and contributors. Tape notes contain track listings of songs, dates of    performances, and names of performers. Broadside Broadside Broadside Broadside Broadside Broadside

nameEntries.original: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Library. Southern Folklife Collection.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Liberian Collections</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Indiana University</addressline>
                        <addressline>504 North Fess Avenue</addressline>
                        <addressline>Bloomington, IN 47408</addressline>
                        <addressline>Phone: (812) 856-0782</addressline>
                        <addressline>Email: liberia@indiana.edu </addressline>
                     </address>
                     <lb/>
                     <extref>http://www.onliberia.org</extref>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>d'Azevedo, Warren</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Warren d'Azevedo Collection, <unitdate>1935-2001</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <unitid>LCP2001/001</unitid>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>29 cubic feet; </extent>
                     <extent>29 records cartons</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <physloc>LCP300</physloc>
                  <langmaterial>Materials are primarily in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <abstract> Warren d’Azevedo is a retired
                ethnographer, renowned for his work in anthropology and African studies. D’Azevedo
                began his research in the 1950s, focusing primarily on African cultures, including
                the Gola ethnic group of Liberia and the Native American Washoe culture of the Great
                Basin. This collection consists of d’Azevedo’s writings, photographs, memorabilia,
                and U.S. and Liberian government documents and teaching materials.  </abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Warren d'Azevedo Collection, 1935-2001
resource.abstract: Warren d’Azevedo is a retired                ethnographer, renowned for his work in anthropology and African studies. D’Azevedo                began his research in the 1950s, focusing primarily on African cultures, including                the Gola ethnic group of Liberia and the Native American Washoe culture of the Great                Basin. This collection consists of d’Azevedo’s writings, photographs, memorabilia,                and U.S. and Liberian government documents and teaching materials.

nameEntries.original: Liberian Collectionshttp://www.onliberia.org

address.text: Liberian Collections Indiana University 504 North Fess Avenue Bloomington, IN 47408 Phone: (812) 856-0782 Email: liberia@indiana.edu

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:761310454</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-QQS</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Nancy Ryan Barkman collection 1949-2000 [manuscript]</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Nancy Ryan Barkman collection contains programs and booklets from Pittsburgh cultural events. There are two Civic Light Opera Programs for Naughty Marietta and Brigadoon, performed in the 1949-1950 season at Pitt Stadium. Included is a Central Catholic High School program from a 1949 production of Rose Maria. The papers contain several Duquesne University items, consisting of a 1955 Military Ball program, a 1954 Gamma Phi 29th Annual Thanksgiving Ball booklet, and a 1954 Duquesne University Tamburtitzans booklet. Additionally, there is 2000 issue of the Pittsburgh Pirates official magazine On Deck, from the teams last season in Three Rivers Stadium. The collection also contains approximately fifty different signed individual school photographs, three postcards Barkman received, a hand fan listing incumbent African American congressmen and women, and additional event programs. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Historical Society of W Pennsylvania</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Nancy Ryan Barkman collection 1949-2000 [manuscript]
resource.abstract: The Nancy Ryan Barkman collection contains programs and booklets from Pittsburgh cultural events. There are two Civic Light Opera Programs for Naughty Marietta and Brigadoon, performed in the 1949-1950 season at Pitt Stadium. Included is a Central Catholic High School program from a 1949 production of Rose Maria. The papers contain several Duquesne University items, consisting of a 1955 Military Ball program, a 1954 Gamma Phi 29th Annual Thanksgiving Ball booklet, and a 1954 Duquesne University Tamburtitzans booklet. Additionally, there is 2000 issue of the Pittsburgh Pirates official magazine On Deck, from the teams last season in Three Rivers Stadium. The collection also contains approximately fifty different signed individual school photographs, three postcards Barkman received, a hand fan listing incumbent African American congressmen and women, and additional event programs.

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Henry Ellenbogen papers 1918-1985 [papers].</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Henry Ellenbogen papers are arranged in six series. Series have been designated for personal papers, law practice, congressional papers, labor relations, judicial papers and United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs. These papers include biographical information, correspondence, personal scrapbooks, organizational materials and other sundry materials. The papers primarily relate to Ellenbogen's professional life and do not offer much personal or family information. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Historical Society of W Pennsylvania</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Henry Ellenbogen papers 1918-1985 [papers].
resource.abstract: The Henry Ellenbogen papers are arranged in six series. Series have been designated for personal papers, law practice, congressional papers, labor relations, judicial papers and United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs. These papers include biographical information, correspondence, personal scrapbooks, organizational materials and other sundry materials. The papers primarily relate to Ellenbogen's professional life and do not offer much personal or family information.

                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>[Letter, 2000 Dec. 5 : to Fred Rogers].</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Dettore writes about Fred Rogers' impact in the field of child development.  He is happy that Rogers will still be working on projects after he finishes "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood." </abstract>
                  <name>
